handNote.p: Ker's scribe '(1)' of 'seven or eight'. A round Anglo-Saxon miniscule. Round, unroofed a; a mixture of descending insular long s and tall s; round d with short ascender; ash is of oe-form and sometimes with tall e. e is horned, with a short tongue. Ascenders of tall letters are wedged, leaning towards forking. A slight lean to the right. This scribe is also responsible for a number of small c-shaped accents that indicate short vowel quality, particularly for disambiguating between god/'God' and gōd/'good'. See further Ker's Catalogue on the script's relationship to several MSS of Exeter.

An emending hand replacing a large number of instances of 'on' with 'in', replacing 'in' with 'on', and making some other adjustments oriented to language change. The on-to-in and in-to-on changes are made with an underline and an interlinear insertion above the changed word, while other adjustments are made with a simple flick-like insertion mark or en expunction. The script uses the same letterforms as the main scribe's script, but the hand is a bit rounder and more vertical. DP0584a is responsible for the majority of the emendations, but other hands also appear in a few isolated corrections.
